mn12:0.2.eng: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

mn12:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati bahinagare aparapure vanasaṇḍe.
mn12:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying outside the city of Vesālī in a woodland grove west of the town.
mn12:1.2.comm: This description of the Buddha’s location is unique.

mn12:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sunakkhatto licchaviputto acirapakkanto hoti imasmā dhammavinayā.
mn12:2.1.eng: Now at that time Sunakkhatta the Licchavi had recently left this teaching and training.
mn12:2.1.comm: Sunakkhatta’s dismal spiritual career began when he met the Buddha in MN 105. In DN 6:5.3 we learn that, after being ordained three years, he spoke of his limited success in meditation. The current sutta and DN 24 deal with Sunakkhatta’s bitter criticisms of the Buddha shortly after his disrobal.

mn12:2.2.pli: So vesāliyaṃ parisati evaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati:
mn12:2.2.eng: He was telling a crowd in Vesālī:

mn12:2.3.eng: “The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
mn12:2.3.comm: These distinctions are defined in the Vinaya as “absorption, release, immersion, attainment, knowledge and vision, development of the path, realization of the fruits, giving up the defilements, a mind without hindrances, delighting in an empty dwelling” (Bu Pj 4:3.8). They may be summarized as absorption, psychic abilities, and realization of the paths and fruits.

mn12:2.4.pli: Takkapariyāhataṃ samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ deseti vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayampaṭibhānaṃ.
mn12:2.4.eng: He teaches what he’s worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing his own perspective.
mn12:2.4.comm: The Buddha taught that logic alone is an unreliable guide to the truth (MN 76:27.2, DN 1:1.34.2), a fact of which Sunakkhatta was apparently not aware.

mn12:2.5.pli: Yassa ca khvāssa atthāya dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā”ti.
mn12:2.5.eng: And his teaching leads those who practice it to the complete ending of suffering, the goal for which it’s taught.”
mn12:2.5.comm: The Chinese parallel at T 757, rather, raises the question, “How could such a teaching lead to freedom from suffering?”

mn12:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya vesāliṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
mn12:3.1.eng: Then Venerable Sāriputta robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.

mn12:3.2.pli: Assosi kho āyasmā sāriputto sunakkhattassa licchaviputtassa vesāliyaṃ parisati evaṃ vācaṃ bhāsamānassa:
mn12:3.2.eng: He heard what Sunakkhatta was saying.

mn12:3.4.pli: Takkapariyāhataṃ samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ deseti vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayampaṭibhānaṃ.

mn12:3.5.pli: Yassa ca khvāssa atthāya dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā”ti.

mn12:3.6.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto vesāliyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn12:3.6.eng: Then he wandered for alms in Vesālī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

mn12:3.8.pli: So vesāliyaṃ parisati evaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati:

mn12:3.10.pli: Takkapariyāhataṃ samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ deseti vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayampaṭibhānaṃ.

mn12:3.11.pli: Yassa ca khvāssa atthāya dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’”ti.

mn12:4.1.eng: “Sāriputta, Sunakkhatta, that futile man, is angry.
mn12:4.1.comm: “Futile man” (moghapurisa) refers to someone who has been led astray by delusion.

mn12:4.2.pli: Kodhā ca panassa esā vācā bhāsitā.
mn12:4.2.eng: His words are spoken out of anger.

mn12:4.3.pli: ‘Avaṇṇaṃ bhāsissāmī’ti kho, sāriputta, sunakkhatto moghapuriso vaṇṇaṃyeva tathāgatassa bhāsati.
mn12:4.3.eng: Thinking he criticizes the Realized One, in fact he just praises him.

mn12:4.4.pli: Vaṇṇo heso, sāriputta, tathāgatassa yo evaṃ vadeyya:
mn12:4.4.eng: For it is praise of the Realized One to say:

mn12:4.5.pli: ‘yassa ca khvāssa atthāya dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’ti.
mn12:4.5.eng: ‘His teaching leads those who practice it to the complete ending of suffering, the goal for which it’s taught.’

mn12:5.1.pli: Ayampi hi nāma, sāriputta, sunakkhattassa moghapurisassa mayi dhammanvayo na bhavissati:
mn12:5.1.eng: But there’s no way Sunakkhatta will infer about me from the teaching:
mn12:5.1.comm: “Inference from the teaching” (dhammanvaya) is a valid form of knowledge, where someone draws a reasoned conclusion based on fundamental principles (see SN 12.33:7.2).

mn12:5.2.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi, satthā devamanussānaṃ, buddho bhagavā’ti.
mn12:5.2.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

mn12:6.1.pli: Ayampi hi nāma, sāriputta, sunakkhattassa moghapurisassa mayi dhammanvayo na bhavissati:
mn12:6.1.eng: And there’s no way Sunakkhatta will infer about me from the teaching:

mn12:6.2.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti; āvibhāvaṃ, tirobhāvaṃ; tirokuṭṭaṃ tiropākāraṃ tiropabbataṃ asajjamāno gacchati, seyyathāpi ākāse; pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṃ karoti, seyyathāpi udake; udakepi abhijjamāne gacchati, seyyathāpi pathaviyaṃ; ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamati, seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo; imepi candimasūriye evaṃmahiddhike evaṃmahānubhāve pāṇinā parimasati parimajjati; yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vattetī’ti.
mn12:6.2.eng: ‘That Blessed One wields the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying himself and becoming one again; materializing and dematerializing; going unobstructed through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.’
mn12:6.2.comm: The Buddha introduces these here because, as we know from DN 24:1.4.1, Sunakkhatta thought that such displays were a worthy goal of spiritual practice. The Chinese parallel, however, omits the psychic powers and instead has the jhānas. | This passage begins the six direct knowledges.

mn12:7.1.pli: Ayampi hi nāma, sāriputta, sunakkhattassa moghapurisassa mayi dhammanvayo na bhavissati:
mn12:7.1.eng: And there’s no way Sunakkhatta will infer about me from the teaching:

mn12:7.2.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti—dibbe ca mānuse ca, ye dūre santike cā’ti.
mn12:7.2.eng: ‘That Blessed One, with clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, hears both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.’

mn12:8.1.pli: Ayampi hi nāma, sāriputta, sunakkhattassa moghapurisassa mayi dhammanvayo na bhavissati:
mn12:8.1.eng: And there’s no way Sunakkhatta will infer about me from the teaching:

mn12:8.2.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti—
mn12:8.2.eng: ‘That Blessed One understands the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with his own mind.

mn12:8.3.pli: sarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ sarāgaṃ cittanti pajānāti,
mn12:8.3.eng: He understands mind with greed as “mind with greed,”

mn12:8.4.pli: vītarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ vītarāgaṃ cittanti pajānāti;
mn12:8.4.eng: and mind without greed as “mind without greed.”

mn12:8.5.pli: sadosaṃ vā cittaṃ sadosaṃ cittanti pajānāti,

mn12:8.6.pli: vītadosaṃ vā cittaṃ vītadosaṃ cittanti pajānāti;

mn12:8.7.pli: samohaṃ vā cittaṃ samohaṃ cittanti pajānāti,

mn12:8.8.pli: vītamohaṃ vā cittaṃ vītamohaṃ cittanti pajānāti;

mn12:8.9.pli: saṅkhittaṃ vā cittaṃ saṅkhittaṃ cittanti pajānāti,

mn12:8.10.pli: vikkhittaṃ vā cittaṃ vikkhittaṃ cittanti pajānāti;

mn12:8.11.pli: mahaggataṃ vā cittaṃ mahaggataṃ cittanti pajānāti,

mn12:8.12.pli: amahaggataṃ vā cittaṃ amahaggataṃ cittanti pajānāti;

mn12:8.13.pli: sauttaraṃ vā cittaṃ sauttaraṃ cittanti pajānāti,

mn12:8.14.pli: anuttaraṃ vā cittaṃ anuttaraṃ cittanti pajānāti;

mn12:8.15.pli: samāhitaṃ vā cittaṃ samāhitaṃ cittanti pajānāti,

mn12:8.16.pli: asamāhitaṃ vā cittaṃ asamāhitaṃ cittanti pajānāti;

mn12:8.17.pli: vimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ cittanti pajānāti,

mn12:8.18.pli: avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ avimuttaṃ cittanti pajānātī’ti.

mn12:9.1.pli: Dasa kho panimāni, sāriputta, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalāni yehi balehi samannāgato tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
mn12:9.1.eng: There are these ten powers of a Realized One that the Realized One possesses. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.
mn12:9.1.comm: After the first three of the direct knowledges, the sequence is interrupted with the insertion of these ten powers of a Realized One, also found at AN 10.21 and AN 10.22. The Vibhaṅga, an early Abhidhamma book, gives a detailed explanation (Vb 16:353 ff.). | Five powers are listed at AN 5.11 and six at AN 6.64.

mn12:10.1.pli: Idha, sāriputta, tathāgato ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
mn12:10.1.eng: Firstly, the Realized One truly understands the possible as possible, and the impossible as impossible.

mn12:10.2.pli: Yampi, sāriputta, tathāgato ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, idampi, sāriputta, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
mn12:10.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. Relying on this he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.

mn12:11.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, sāriputta, tathāgato atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ kammasamādānānaṃ ṭhānaso hetuso vipākaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
mn12:11.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the result of deeds undertaken in the past, future, and present in terms of grounds and causes.
mn12:11.1.comm: The Vibhaṅga explains this as knowing the circumstances that prevent or support the fruition of deeds, namely: place of rebirth (gati), form of reincarnation (upadhi, explained by the commentary as attabhāva), time (kāla), and effort (payoga). | See also the analysis of “deeds” (kamma) in MN 57, MN 135, and MN 136.

mn12:11.2.pli: Yampi, sāriputta, tathāgato atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ kammasamādānānaṃ ṭhānaso hetuso vipākaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, idampi, sāriputta, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
mn12:11.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

mn12:12.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, sāriputta, tathāgato sabbatthagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
mn12:12.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands where all paths of practice lead.

mn12:12.2.pli: Yampi, sāriputta, tathāgato sabbatthagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, idampi, sāriputta, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
mn12:12.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

mn12:13.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, sāriputta, tathāgato anekadhātunānādhātulokaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
mn12:13.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the world with its many and diverse elements.

mn12:13.2.pli: Yampi, sāriputta, tathāgato anekadhātunānādhātulokaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, idampi, sāriputta, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
mn12:13.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

mn12:14.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, sāriputta, tathāgato sattānaṃ nānādhimuttikataṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
mn12:14.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the diverse convictions of sentient beings.
mn12:14.1.comm: This is not explained explicitly, but an example is found at DN 1:1.3.2, where the Buddha knows the difference between Brahmadatta, who had faith in the triple gem, and Suppiya who did not. Thus adhimutti (“conviction”) means “faith, belief” rather than “disposition”.

mn12:14.2.pli: Yampi, sāriputta, tathāgato sattānaṃ nānādhimuttikataṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, idampi, sāriputta, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
mn12:14.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

mn12:15.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, sāriputta, tathāgato parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ indriyaparopariyattaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
mn12:15.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the faculties of other sentient beings and other individuals after encompassing them with his mind.
mn12:15.1.comm: Exemplified by the Buddha when he surveyed the world after his awakening to see the diverse spiritual potentials of beings (MN 26:21.2, MN 85:45.4, DN 14:3.6.2, SN 6.1:9.2, Kd 1:5.11.1).

mn12:15.2.pli: Yampi, sāriputta, tathāgato parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ indriyaparopariyattaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, idampi, sāriputta, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
mn12:15.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

mn12:16.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, sāriputta, tathāgato jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnaṃ saṅkilesaṃ vodānaṃ vuṭṭhānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
mn12:16.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands corruption, cleansing, and emergence regarding the absorptions, liberations, immersions, and attainments.
mn12:16.1.comm: “Corruption” is any mental factor that darkens and diminishes meditation; “cleansing” is anything that brightens and enhances it. “Emergence” refers to understanding the reasons why one comes out of a given state of meditation (eg. MN 43:29.1). | The phrase “absorptions, liberations, immersions, and attainments” indicates that, although they are given various technical definitions, these are overlapping terms that describe in different ways the same field of deep meditation experiences.

mn12:16.2.pli: Yampi, sāriputta, tathāgato jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnaṃ saṅkilesaṃ vodānaṃ vuṭṭhānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, idampi, sāriputta, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
mn12:16.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

mn12:17.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, sāriputta, tathāgato anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
mn12:17.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One recollects many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. He remembers: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so he recollects his many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
mn12:17.1.comm: Here we return to the final three of the six direct knowledges, which also form the final three of the ten powers.

mn12:17.2.pli: Yampi, sāriputta, tathāgato anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, idampi, sāriputta, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
mn12:17.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

mn12:18.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, sāriputta, tathāgato dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
mn12:18.1.eng: Furthermore, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, the Realized One sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds. ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, he sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

mn12:18.2.pli: Yampi, sāriputta, tathāgato dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti. Idampi, sāriputta, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
mn12:18.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

mn12:19.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, sāriputta, tathāgato āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
mn12:19.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.

mn12:19.2.pli: Yampi, sāriputta, tathāgato āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati, idampi, sāriputta, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
mn12:19.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. Relying on this he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.

mn12:20.1.pli: Imāni kho, sāriputta, dasa tathāgatassa tathāgatabalāni yehi balehi samannāgato tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
mn12:20.1.eng: A Realized One possesses these ten powers of a Realized One. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.

mn12:21.1.pli: Yo kho maṃ, sāriputta, evaṃ jānantaṃ evaṃ passantaṃ evaṃ vadeyya:
mn12:21.1.eng: When I know and see in this way, suppose someone were to say this:

mn12:21.2.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.

mn12:21.3.pli: takkapariyāhataṃ samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ deseti vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayampaṭibhānan’ti,
mn12:21.3.eng: He teaches what he’s worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing his own perspective.’

mn12:21.4.pli: taṃ, sāriputta, vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
mn12:21.4.eng: Unless they give up that speech and that thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell.
mn12:21.4.comm: This seems harsh, but the suttas see such denigration of the Buddha as deeply wicked, since it closes off the path to Nibbana, as at SN 42.9:4.12 where a village chief accuses the Buddha of destroying families by encouraging renunciation. At DN 24:1.16.13 the Buddha warns Sunakkhatta that the naked ascetic Pāṭikaputta, without likewise giving up his speech, thought, and view, will not even be able to enter the Buddha’s presence, much less debate him.

mn12:21.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, bhikkhu sīlasampanno samādhisampanno paññāsampanno diṭṭheva dhamme aññaṃ ārādheyya, evaṃ sampadamidaṃ, sāriputta, vadāmi.
mn12:21.5.eng: Just as a mendicant accomplished in ethics, immersion, and wisdom would reach enlightenment in this very life, such is the consequence, I say.

mn12:21.6.pli: Taṃ vācaṃ appahāya, taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
mn12:21.6.eng: Unless they give up that speech and that thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell.

mn12:22.1.pli: Cattārimāni, sāriputta, tathāgatassa vesārajjāni yehi vesārajjehi samannāgato tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
mn12:22.1.eng: Sāriputta, a Realized One has four kinds of self-assurance. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.
mn12:22.1.comm: These four “kinds of self-assurance” (vesārajja) are also found at AN 4.8. The first three are included in the Buddha’s dressing down of Sarabha at AN 3.64.

mn12:23.1.pli: ‘Sammāsambuddhassa te paṭijānato ime dhammā anabhisambuddhā’ti. Tatra vata maṃ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṃ sahadhammena paṭicodessatīti nimittametaṃ, sāriputta, na samanupassāmi.
mn12:23.1.eng: I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or the Divinity, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately scold me, saying: ‘You claim to be a fully awakened Buddha, but you don’t understand these things.’
mn12:23.1.comm: In his first discourse, the Buddha says that he did not claim to be fully awakened until he had understand the four noble truths in all three rounds and twelve aspects (SN 56.11:10.1). | Here nimitta means “reason, ground, basis”.

mn12:23.2.pli: Etamahaṃ, sāriputta, nimittaṃ asamanupassanto khemappatto abhayappatto vesārajjappatto viharāmi.
mn12:23.2.eng: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.

mn12:24.1.pli: ‘Khīṇāsavassa te paṭijānato ime āsavā aparikkhīṇā’ti. Tatra vata maṃ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṃ sahadhammena paṭicodessatīti nimittametaṃ, sāriputta, na samanupassāmi.
mn12:24.1.eng: I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or the Divinity, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately scold me, saying: ‘You claim to have ended all defilements, but you still have these defilements.’

mn12:24.2.pli: Etamahaṃ, sāriputta, nimittaṃ asamanupassanto khemappatto abhayappatto vesārajjappatto viharāmi.
mn12:24.2.eng: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.

mn12:25.1.pli: ‘Ye kho pana te antarāyikā dhammā vuttā, te paṭisevato nālaṃ antarāyāyā’ti. Tatra vata maṃ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṃ sahadhammena paṭicodessatīti nimittametaṃ, sāriputta, na samanupassāmi.
mn12:25.1.eng: I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or the Divinity, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately scold me, saying: ‘The acts that you say are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them.’
mn12:25.1.comm: This was the accusation of Ariṭṭha (MN 22). The Chinese parallel identifies the “obstructions” as desire and lust.

mn12:25.2.pli: Etamahaṃ, sāriputta, nimittaṃ asamanupassanto khemappatto abhayappatto vesārajjappatto viharāmi.
mn12:25.2.eng: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.

mn12:26.1.pli: ‘Yassa kho pana te atthāya dhammo desito, so na niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’ti. Tatra vata maṃ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṃ sahadhammena paṭicodessatīti nimittametaṃ, sāriputta, na samanupassāmi.
mn12:26.1.eng: I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or the Divinity, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately scold me, saying: ‘The teaching doesn’t lead those who practice it to the complete ending of suffering, the goal for which it is taught.’

mn12:26.2.pli: Etamahaṃ, sāriputta, nimittaṃ asamanupassanto khemappatto abhayappatto vesārajjappatto viharāmi.
mn12:26.2.eng: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.

mn12:27.1.pli: Imāni kho, sāriputta, cattāri tathāgatassa vesārajjāni yehi vesārajjehi samannāgato tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
mn12:27.1.eng: A Realized One possesses these four kinds of self-assurance. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.

mn12:28.1.pli: Yo kho maṃ, sāriputta, evaṃ jānantaṃ evaṃ passantaṃ evaṃ vadeyya:
mn12:28.1.eng: When I know and see in this way, suppose someone were to say this:

mn12:28.2.pli: ‘natthi samaṇassa gotamassa uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso, takkapariyāhataṃ samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ deseti vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayampaṭibhānan’ti,
mn12:28.2.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones …’

mn12:28.5.pli: Taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.

mn12:29.1.eng: Sāriputta, there are these eight assemblies.
mn12:29.1.comm: Mentioned also at AN 8.69, DN 16:3.21.3, and DN 33:3.1.139.

mn12:29.3.pli: Khattiyaparisā, brāhmaṇaparisā, gahapatiparisā, samaṇaparisā, cātumahārājikaparisā, tāvatiṃsaparisā, māraparisā, brahmaparisā—
mn12:29.3.eng: The assemblies of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics. An assembly of the gods of the four great kings. An assembly of the gods of the thirty-three. An assembly of Māras. An assembly of divinities.

mn12:29.5.pli: Imehi kho, sāriputta, catūhi vesārajjehi samannāgato tathāgato imā aṭṭha parisā upasaṅkamati ajjhogāhati.
mn12:29.5.eng: Possessing these four kinds of self-assurance, the Realized One approaches and enters right into these eight assemblies.
mn12:29.5.comm: AN 8.69 and DN 16:3.21.3 both relate the Buddha entering these assemblies, but neither they, nor the Chinese parallel to this passage, attribute his confidence to the four kinds of self-assurance.

mn12:29.6.pli: Abhijānāmi kho panāhaṃ, sāriputta, anekasataṃ khattiyaparisaṃ upasaṅkamitā.
mn12:29.6.eng: I recall having approached an assembly of hundreds of aristocrats.
mn12:29.6.comm: Anekasataṁ khattiyaparisaṁ is singular, “an assembly of hundreds of aristocrats”, rather than “hundreds of assemblies of aristocrats”.

mn12:29.7.pli: Tatrapi mayā sannisinnapubbañceva, sallapitapubbañca, sākacchā ca samāpajjitapubbā.
mn12:29.7.eng: There I used to sit with them, converse, and engage in discussion.

mn12:29.8.pli: Tatra vata maṃ bhayaṃ vā sārajjaṃ vā okkamissatīti nimittametaṃ, sāriputta, na samanupassāmi.
mn12:29.8.eng: But I don’t see any reason to feel afraid or insecure.

mn12:29.9.pli: Etamahaṃ, sāriputta, nimittaṃ asamanupassanto khemappatto abhayappatto vesārajjappatto viharāmi.
mn12:29.9.eng: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.

mn12:30.1.pli: Abhijānāmi kho panāhaṃ, sāriputta, anekasataṃ brāhmaṇaparisaṃ …pe…
mn12:30.1.eng: I recall having approached an assembly of hundreds of brahmins …

mn12:30.4.eng: the gods of the four great kings …

mn12:30.8.eng: There too I used to sit with them, converse, and engage in discussion.

mn12:30.9.pli: Tatra vata maṃ bhayaṃ vā sārajjaṃ vā okkamissatīti nimittametaṃ, sāriputta, na samanupassāmi.
mn12:30.9.eng: But I don’t see any reason to feel afraid or insecure.

mn12:30.10.pli: Etamahaṃ, sāriputta, nimittaṃ asamanupassanto khemappatto abhayappatto vesārajjappatto viharāmi.
mn12:30.10.eng: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.

mn12:31.1.eng: When I know and see in this way, suppose someone were to say this:

mn12:31.2.pli: ‘natthi samaṇassa gotamassa uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso, takkapariyāhataṃ samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ deseti vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayampaṭibhānan’ti,

mn12:32.1.eng: Sāriputta, there are these four kinds of reproduction.
mn12:32.1.comm: These four, which are absent from the Chinese parallel, describe the births of different kinds of nāga (SN 29.1) and phoenix (SN 30.1).

mn12:32.3.pli: Aṇḍajā yoni, jalābujā yoni, saṃsedajā yoni, opapātikā yoni.
mn12:32.3.eng: Reproduction for creatures born from an egg, from a womb, from moisture, or spontaneously.
mn12:32.3.comm: Compare the three “seeds” of Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.3.1: beings are born from an egg (āṇḍaja), from a living individual (jīvaja, i.e. “viviparous”), from a sprout (udbhijja, i.e. plants). Expanded to four at Aitareya Upaniṣad 3.3: from an egg, from a membrane (jāruja = jarāyuja, cf. Pali jalābuja), from moisture/sweat (svedaja, cf. Pali saṁsedaja), from a sprout. These are defined at Manusmṛti 1.43–6. The Jain Tattvārtha Sūtra 2.31–5 presents three kinds of birth: congealing (sammūrcchana), uterine (garbha; includes egg and womb), and spontaneous (upapāda, cf. Pali opapātika in the same sense). “Congealing” birth refers to all those not otherwise covered, and thus includes both “mosisture-born” and plants (cf. DN 15:21.2). | The Buddhist list is the only one that does not include plants, as Buddhists believe that consciousness does not take rebirth in plants. The Vedic position is that the soul (ātman) can be reborn in plants (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.3.2), while the Jains believed that all things living and not living possess souls (jīva).

mn12:33.1.eng: And what is reproduction from an egg?

mn12:33.2.pli: Ye kho te, sāriputta, sattā aṇḍakosaṃ abhinibbhijja jāyanti—
mn12:33.2.eng: There are beings who are born by breaking out of an eggshell.

mn12:33.3.eng: This is called reproduction from an egg.

mn12:33.4.eng: And what is reproduction from a womb?
mn12:33.4.comm: This is literally “membranous” reproduction, in reference to the membranes that envelop the fetus.

mn12:33.5.pli: Ye kho te, sāriputta, sattā vatthikosaṃ abhinibbhijja jāyanti—
mn12:33.5.eng: There are beings who are born by breaking out of the amniotic sac.

mn12:33.6.eng: This is called reproduction from a womb.

mn12:33.7.eng: And what is reproduction from moisture?

mn12:33.8.pli: Ye kho te, sāriputta, sattā pūtimacche vā jāyanti pūtikuṇape vā pūtikummāse vā candanikāye vā oḷigalle vā jāyanti—
mn12:33.8.eng: There are beings who are born in a rotten fish, in a rotten carcass, in rotten dough, in a cesspool or a sump.

mn12:33.9.eng: This is called reproduction from moisture.

mn12:33.11.pli: Devā, nerayikā, ekacce ca manussā, ekacce ca vinipātikā—
mn12:33.11.eng: Gods, hell-beings, certain humans, and certain beings in the lower realms.

mn12:33.13.eng: These are the four kinds of reproduction.

mn12:34.5.pli: Taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.

mn12:35.3.eng: Hell, the animal realm, the ghost realm, humanity, and the gods.
mn12:35.3.comm: The asuras (“titans”) are included with the gods in this classification; gods and titans are close enough to allow intermarriage (SN 11.13:11.1). The Chinese parallel, in common with later traditions, adds the titans as a separate realm here.

mn12:36.1.pli: Nirayañcāhaṃ, sāriputta, pajānāmi, nirayagāmiñca maggaṃ, nirayagāminiñca paṭipadaṃ;
mn12:36.1.eng: I understand hell, and the path and practice that leads to hell.

mn12:36.2.pli: yathā paṭipanno ca kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati tañca pajānāmi.
mn12:36.2.eng: And I understand how someone practicing that way, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

mn12:36.3.pli: Tiracchānayoniñcāhaṃ, sāriputta, pajānāmi, tiracchānayonigāmiñca maggaṃ, tiracchānayonigāminiñca paṭipadaṃ;

mn12:36.4.pli: yathā paṭipanno ca kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā tiracchānayoniṃ upapajjati tañca pajānāmi.

mn12:36.5.pli: Pettivisayañcāhaṃ, sāriputta, pajānāmi, pettivisayagāmiñca maggaṃ, pettivisayagāminiñca paṭipadaṃ;

mn12:36.6.pli: yathā paṭipanno ca kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā pettivisayaṃ upapajjati tañca pajānāmi.

mn12:36.7.pli: Manusse cāhaṃ, sāriputta, pajānāmi, manussalokagāmiñca maggaṃ, manussalokagāminiñca paṭipadaṃ;

mn12:36.8.pli: yathā paṭipanno ca kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā manussesu upapajjati tañca pajānāmi.

mn12:36.9.pli: Deve cāhaṃ, sāriputta, pajānāmi, devalokagāmiñca maggaṃ, devalokagāminiñca paṭipadaṃ;
mn12:36.9.eng: gods, and the path and practice that leads to the world of the gods.

mn12:36.10.pli: yathā paṭipanno ca kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati tañca pajānāmi.
mn12:36.10.eng: And I understand how someone practicing that way, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

mn12:36.11.pli: Nibbānañcāhaṃ, sāriputta, pajānāmi, nibbānagāmiñca maggaṃ, nibbānagāminiñca paṭipadaṃ;
mn12:36.11.eng: And I understand extinguishment, and the path and practice that leads to extinguishment.

mn12:36.12.pli: yathā paṭipanno ca āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati tañca pajānāmi.
mn12:36.12.eng: And I understand how someone practicing that way realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

mn12:37.1.pli: Idhāhaṃ, sāriputta, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ evaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—
mn12:37.1.eng: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain individual, I understand:
mn12:37.1.comm: Here the Buddha describes the process by which he knows where paths lead. First he comprehends their minds, then he infers their destiny, then he confirms the outcome. It is only in this limited way that he knows the future. If, as popular tradition would have it, he was literally omniscient, there would be no need to undertake such a laborious process involving inference, as he could simply directly see whatever he wanted.

mn12:37.2.pli: tathāyaṃ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṃ samārūḷho, yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjissatīti.
mn12:37.2.eng: ‘This individual is practicing in such a way and is riding upon such a path that when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.’

mn12:37.3.pli: Tamenaṃ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannaṃ, ekantadukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānaṃ.
mn12:37.3.eng: Some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn in hell, where they experience exclusively painful feelings, sharp and severe.

mn12:37.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, aṅgārakāsu sādhikaporisā pūrā aṅgārānaṃ vītaccikānaṃ vītadhūmānaṃ.
mn12:37.4.eng: Suppose there was a pit of glowing coals deeper than a man’s height, full of glowing coals that neither flamed nor smoked.
mn12:37.4.comm: Such pits are frequently mentioned in the suttas and must have been a common sight. Since fired bricks were not regularly produced, perhaps they were used for metals or pottery, although kilns are also mentioned (AN 7.66:8.3, SN 12.51:12.1).

mn12:37.5.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya ghammābhitatto ghammapareto kilanto tasito pipāsito ekāyanena maggena tameva aṅgārakāsuṃ paṇidhāya.
mn12:37.5.eng: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. And they have set out on a path that meets with that same pit of coals.

mn12:37.6.pli: Tamenaṃ cakkhumā puriso disvā evaṃ vadeyya:
mn12:37.6.eng: If a person with clear eyes saw them, they’d say:

mn12:37.7.pli: ‘tathāyaṃ bhavaṃ puriso paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṃ samārūḷho, yathā imaṃyeva aṅgārakāsuṃ āgamissatī’ti.
mn12:37.7.eng: ‘This person is proceeding in such a way and is riding upon such a path that they will arrive at that very pit of coals.’

mn12:37.8.pli: Tamenaṃ passeyya aparena samayena tassā aṅgārakāsuyā patitaṃ, ekantadukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānaṃ.
mn12:37.8.eng: Some time later they see that they have indeed fallen into that pit of coals, where they experience exclusively painful feelings, sharp and severe. …

mn12:37.9.pli: Evameva kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, idhekaccaṃ puggalaṃ evaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—

mn12:37.10.pli: tathāyaṃ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṃ samārūḷho yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjissatīti.

mn12:37.11.pli: Tamenaṃ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannaṃ, ekantadukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānaṃ.

mn12:38.1.pli: Idha panāhaṃ, sāriputta, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ evaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—
mn12:38.1.eng: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain individual, I understand:

mn12:38.2.pli: tathāyaṃ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṃ samārūḷho, yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā tiracchānayoniṃ upapajjissatīti.
mn12:38.2.eng: ‘This individual … will be reborn in the animal realm.’

mn12:38.3.pli: Tamenaṃ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā tiracchānayoniṃ upapannaṃ, dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānaṃ.
mn12:38.3.eng: Some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn in the animal realm, where they suffer painful feelings, sharp and severe.
mn12:38.3.comm: Text omits ekanta (“exclusively”), as animals experience both pleasure and pain.

mn12:38.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, gūthakūpo sādhikaporiso, pūro gūthassa.
mn12:38.4.eng: Suppose there was a sewer deeper than a man’s height, full to the brim with feces.

mn12:38.5.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya ghammābhitatto ghammapareto kilanto tasito pipāsito ekāyanena maggena tameva gūthakūpaṃ paṇidhāya.
mn12:38.5.eng: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. And they have set out on a path that meets with that same sewer.

mn12:38.6.pli: Tamenaṃ cakkhumā puriso disvā evaṃ vadeyya:
mn12:38.6.eng: If a person with clear eyes saw them, they’d say:

mn12:38.7.pli: ‘tathāyaṃ bhavaṃ puriso paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṃ samārūḷho yathā imaṃyeva gūthakūpaṃ āgamissatī’ti.
mn12:38.7.eng: ‘This person is proceeding in such a way and is riding upon such a path that they will arrive at that very sewer.’

mn12:38.8.pli: Tamenaṃ passeyya aparena samayena tasmiṃ gūthakūpe patitaṃ, dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānaṃ.
mn12:38.8.eng: Some time later they see that they have indeed fallen into that sewer, where they suffer painful feelings, sharp and severe. …

mn12:38.9.pli: Evameva kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, idhekaccaṃ puggalaṃ evaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—

mn12:38.10.pli: tathāyaṃ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṃ samārūḷho, yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā tiracchānayoniṃ upapajjissatīti.

mn12:38.11.pli: Tamenaṃ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā tiracchānayoniṃ upapannaṃ, dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānaṃ.

mn12:39.1.pli: Idha panāhaṃ, sāriputta, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ evaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—
mn12:39.1.eng: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain individual, I understand:

mn12:39.2.pli: tathāyaṃ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṃ samārūḷho, yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā pettivisayaṃ upapajjissatīti.
mn12:39.2.eng: ‘This individual … will be reborn in the ghost realm.’

mn12:39.3.pli: Tamenaṃ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā pettivisayaṃ upapannaṃ, dukkhabahulā vedanā vedayamānaṃ.
mn12:39.3.eng: Some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn in the ghost realm, where they experience mostly painful feelings.
mn12:39.3.comm: The pain in the ghost realm is not sharp, severe, and exclusive like in hell, nor just sharp and severe as in the animal realm, but merely “mostly painful” (dukkhabahulā vedanā). The pain level is gradually diminishing, and with the human realm it flips, becoming mostly pleasant, then exclusively pleasant in the heaven realms.

mn12:39.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, rukkho visame bhūmibhāge jāto tanupattapalāso kabaracchāyo.
mn12:39.4.eng: Suppose there was a tree growing on rugged ground, with thin foliage casting dappled shade.
mn12:39.4.comm: Perhaps the tree was in Australia, where the ground is stony, the leaf coverage scanty, and the flies ravenous.

mn12:39.5.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya ghammābhitatto ghammapareto kilanto tasito pipāsito ekāyanena maggena tameva rukkhaṃ paṇidhāya.
mn12:39.5.eng: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. And they have set out on a path that meets with that same tree.

mn12:39.6.pli: Tamenaṃ cakkhumā puriso disvā evaṃ vadeyya:
mn12:39.6.eng: If a person with clear eyes saw them, they’d say:

mn12:39.7.pli: ‘tathāyaṃ bhavaṃ puriso paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṃ samārūḷho, yathā imaṃyeva rukkhaṃ āgamissatī’ti.
mn12:39.7.eng: ‘This person is proceeding in such a way and is riding upon such a path that they will arrive at that very tree.’

mn12:39.8.pli: Tamenaṃ passeyya, aparena samayena tassa rukkhassa chāyāya nisinnaṃ vā nipannaṃ vā dukkhabahulā vedanā vedayamānaṃ.
mn12:39.8.eng: Some time later they see them sitting or lying under that tree, where they experience mostly painful feelings. …

mn12:39.9.pli: Evameva kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, idhekaccaṃ puggalaṃ evaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—

mn12:39.10.pli: tathāyaṃ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṃ samārūḷho, yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā pettivisayaṃ upapajjissatīti.

mn12:39.11.pli: Tamenaṃ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā pettivisayaṃ upapannaṃ, dukkhabahulā vedanā vedayamānaṃ.

mn12:40.3.eng: Some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn among human beings, where they experience mostly pleasant feelings.

mn12:40.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, rukkho same bhūmibhāge jāto bahalapattapalāso sandacchāyo.
mn12:40.4.eng: Suppose there was a tree growing on smooth ground, with abundant foliage casting dense shade.

mn12:40.7.eng: ‘This person is proceeding in such a way and is riding upon such a path that they will arrive at that very tree.’
