mn12:40.10.pli: tathāyaṃ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṃ samārūḷho yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā manussesu upapajjissatīti.

mn12:40.11.pli: Tamenaṃ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā manussesu upapannaṃ, sukhabahulā vedanā vedayamānaṃ.

mn12:41.1.pli: Idha panāhaṃ, sāriputta, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ evaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi:
mn12:41.1.eng: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain individual, I understand:

mn12:41.2.pli: ‘tathāyaṃ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṃ samārūḷho, yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjissatī’ti.
mn12:41.2.eng: ‘This individual … will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’

mn12:41.3.pli: Tamenaṃ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannaṃ, ekantasukhā vedanā vedayamānaṃ.
mn12:41.3.eng: Some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn in a heavenly realm, where they experience feelings of perfect happiness.

mn12:41.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, pāsādo, tatrāssa kūṭāgāraṃ ullittāvalittaṃ nivātaṃ phusitaggaḷaṃ pihitavātapānaṃ.
mn12:41.4.eng: Suppose there was a stilt longhouse with a peaked roof, plastered inside and out, draft-free, with door fastened and window shuttered.

mn12:41.5.pli: Tatrāssa pallaṅko gonakatthato paṭikatthato paṭalikatthato kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇo sauttaracchado ubhatolohitakūpadhāno.
mn12:41.5.eng: And it had a couch spread with woolen covers—shag-piled, pure white, or embroidered with flowers—and spread with a fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red pillows at both ends.

mn12:41.6.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya ghammābhitatto ghammapareto kilanto tasito pipāsito ekāyanena maggena tameva pāsādaṃ paṇidhāya.
mn12:41.6.eng: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. And they have set out on a path that meets with that same stilt longhouse.

mn12:41.7.pli: Tamenaṃ cakkhumā puriso disvā evaṃ vadeyya:
mn12:41.7.eng: If a person with clear eyes saw them, they’d say:

mn12:41.8.pli: ‘tathāyaṃ bhavaṃ puriso paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṃ samārūḷho, yathā imaṃyeva pāsādaṃ āgamissatī’ti.
mn12:41.8.eng: ‘This person is proceeding in such a way and is riding upon such a path that they will arrive at that very stilt longhouse.’

mn12:41.9.pli: Tamenaṃ passeyya aparena samayena tasmiṃ pāsāde tasmiṃ kūṭāgāre tasmiṃ pallaṅke nisinnaṃ vā nipannaṃ vā ekantasukhā vedanā vedayamānaṃ.
mn12:41.9.eng: Some time later they see them sitting or lying in that stilt longhouse, where they experience feelings of perfect happiness. …

mn12:41.10.pli: Evameva kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, idhekaccaṃ puggalaṃ evaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—

mn12:41.11.pli: tathāyaṃ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṃ samārūḷho yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjissatīti.

mn12:41.12.pli: Tamenaṃ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannaṃ, ekantasukhā vedanā vedayamānaṃ.

mn12:42.1.pli: Idha panāhaṃ, sāriputta, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—
mn12:42.1.eng: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain individual, I understand:

mn12:42.2.pli: tathāyaṃ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṃ samārūḷho, yathā āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissatīti.
mn12:42.2.eng: ‘This individual is practicing in such a way and is riding upon such a path that they will realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

mn12:42.3.pli: Tamenaṃ passāmi aparena samayena āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantaṃ, ekantasukhā vedanā vedayamānaṃ.
mn12:42.3.eng: Some time later I see that they have indeed realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements, experiencing feelings of perfect happiness.

mn12:42.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, pokkharaṇī acchodakā sātodakā sītodakā setakā supatitthā ramaṇīyā.
mn12:42.4.eng: Suppose there was a lotus pond with clear, sweet, cool water, clean, with smooth banks, delightful.

mn12:42.5.eng: Nearby was a dense forest grove.
mn12:42.5.comm: We have met tibba above in the sense of “sharp” feelings. At Mnd 14:58.13, such a forest is said to be one of the four kinds of darkness.

mn12:42.6.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya ghammābhitatto ghammapareto kilanto tasito pipāsito ekāyanena maggena tameva pokkharaṇiṃ paṇidhāya.
mn12:42.6.eng: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. And they have set out on a path that meets with that same lotus pond.

mn12:42.7.pli: Tamenaṃ cakkhumā puriso disvā evaṃ vadeyya:
mn12:42.7.eng: If a person with clear eyes saw them, they’d say:

mn12:42.8.pli: ‘tathā bhavaṃ puriso paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṃ samārūḷho, yathā imaṃyeva pokkharaṇiṃ āgamissatī’ti.
mn12:42.8.eng: ‘This person is proceeding in such a way and is riding upon such a path that they will arrive at that very lotus pond.’

mn12:42.9.pli: Tamenaṃ passeyya aparena samayena taṃ pokkharaṇiṃ ogāhetvā nhāyitvā ca pivitvā ca sabbadarathakilamathapariḷāhaṃ paṭippassambhetvā paccuttaritvā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe nisinnaṃ vā nipannaṃ vā, ekantasukhā vedanā vedayamānaṃ.
mn12:42.9.eng: Some time later they would see that person after they had plunged into that lotus pond, bathed and drunk. When all their stress, weariness, and heat exhaustion had faded away, they emerged and sat or lay down in that woodland thicket, where they experienced feelings of perfect happiness.

mn12:42.10.pli: Evameva kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, idhekaccaṃ puggalaṃ evaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi:
mn12:42.10.eng: In the same way, when I’ve comprehended the mind of an individual, I understand:

mn12:42.11.pli: ‘tathāyaṃ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṃ samārūḷho, yathā āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissatī’ti.
mn12:42.11.eng: ‘This individual is practicing in such a way and is riding upon such a path that they will realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

mn12:42.12.pli: Tamenaṃ passāmi aparena samayena āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantaṃ, ekantasukhā vedanā vedayamānaṃ.
mn12:42.12.eng: Some time later I see that they have indeed realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements, experiencing feelings of perfect happiness.

mn12:43.1.pli: Yo kho maṃ, sāriputta, evaṃ jānantaṃ evaṃ passantaṃ evaṃ vadeyya:
mn12:43.1.eng: When I know and see in this way, suppose someone were to say this:

mn12:43.2.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.

mn12:43.3.pli: takkapariyāhataṃ samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ deseti vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayampaṭibhānan’ti
mn12:43.3.eng: He teaches what he’s worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing his own perspective.’

mn12:43.4.pli: taṃ, sāriputta, vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
mn12:43.4.eng: Unless they give up that speech and that thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell.

mn12:43.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, bhikkhu sīlasampanno samādhisampanno paññāsampanno diṭṭheva dhamme aññaṃ ārādheyya; evaṃ sampadamidaṃ, sāriputta, vadāmi
mn12:43.5.eng: Just as a mendicant accomplished in ethics, immersion, and wisdom would reach enlightenment in this very life, such is the consequence, I say.

mn12:43.6.pli: taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
mn12:43.6.eng: Unless they give up that speech and that thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell.

mn12:44.1.pli: Abhijānāmi kho panāhaṃ, sāriputta, caturaṅgasamannāgataṃ brahmacariyaṃ caritā—
mn12:44.1.eng: Sāriputta, I recall having practiced a spiritual path consisting of four factors.
mn12:44.1.comm: The Buddha evidently introduces this topic because Sunakkhatta was impressed by displays of austerity. It is a unique description of the Bodhisatta’s practices before awakening. The practices, which for the most part sound very Jain-like, were undertaken in various periods during the six years after the Bodhisatta went forth and before his awakening. | The supposedly Jain “fourfold restraint” is recorded at MN 56:12.2 and DN 2:29.2, while at DN 25:16.4 the Buddha reinterprets it as keeping precepts.

mn12:44.2.pli: tapassī sudaṃ homi paramatapassī, lūkho sudaṃ homi paramalūkho, jegucchī sudaṃ homi paramajegucchī, pavivitto sudaṃ homi paramapavivitto.
mn12:44.2.eng: I used to be a fervent mortifier, the ultimate fervent mortifier. I used to live rough, the ultimate rough-liver. I used to live in disgust of sin, the ultimate one living in disgust of sin. I used to be secluded, in ultimate seclusion.
mn12:44.2.comm: “Fervent mortifier” (tapassī), “rough-liver” (lūkha), “one living in disgust of sin” (jegucchī), “secluded” (pavivitta).

mn12:45.1.pli: Tatrāssu me idaṃ, sāriputta, tapassitāya hoti—acelako homi muttācāro hatthāpalekhano, naehibhaddantiko natiṭṭhabhaddantiko; nābhihaṭaṃ na uddissakataṃ na nimantanaṃ sādiyāmi.
mn12:45.1.eng: And this is what my fervent mortification was like. I went naked, ignoring conventions. I licked my hands, and didn’t come or stop when asked. I didn’t consent to food brought to me, or food prepared specially for me, or an invitation for a meal.
mn12:45.1.comm: Tapas (“ardor, fire. fervor, fervent mortification”) is the raging flame of righteous pain that courses through body when it is pushed to its extremes. This “fervor” burns off the corrupting traces of kamma and defilements. | Buddhist mendicants may not receive food in their hands, nor lick them while eating. Followers of the practices listed here would have walked steadily and randomly for alms, accepting only what was given at the time.

mn12:45.2.pli: So na kumbhimukhā paṭiggaṇhāmi, na kaḷopimukhā paṭiggaṇhāmi, na eḷakamantaraṃ, na daṇḍamantaraṃ, na musalamantaraṃ, na dvinnaṃ bhuñjamānānaṃ, na gabbhiniyā, na pāyamānāya, na purisantaragatāya, na saṅkittīsu, na yattha sā upaṭṭhito hoti, na yattha makkhikā saṇḍasaṇḍacārinī; na macchaṃ na maṃsaṃ na suraṃ na merayaṃ na thusodakaṃ pivāmi;
mn12:45.2.eng: I didn’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who lives with a man; or where food for distribution is advertised; or where there’s a hound waiting or flies buzzing. I accepted no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drank no fermented gruel.
mn12:45.2.comm: Keeping sheep (eḷaka, for slaughter) goes against the Jain principle of non-violence, as does keeping weapons (daṇḍa). | A musala often means “pestle”, but it can also be a “shovel”; at MN 81:18.12 it is regarded as a virtue to not use one to dig the soil (which is regarded as being alive in Jainism). | Thusodaka is an alcoholic porridge fermented from grain-husks, mentioned alongside sovīraka in the Pali commentaries and Carakasaṁhitā 27g.191.

mn12:45.3.pli: so ekāgāriko vā homi ekālopiko, dvāgāriko vā homi dvālopiko …pe… sattāgāriko vā homi sattālopiko;
mn12:45.3.eng: I went to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.

mn12:45.4.pli: ekissāpi dattiyā yāpemi, dvīhipi dattīhi yāpemi …pe… sattahipi dattīhi yāpemi;
mn12:45.4.eng: I fed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.

mn12:45.5.pli: ekāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāremi, dvīhikampi āhāraṃ āhāremi …pe… sattāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāremi; iti evarūpaṃ addhamāsikampi pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyutto viharāmi.
mn12:45.5.eng: I ate once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. I lived committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.

mn12:45.6.pli: So sākabhakkho vā homi, sāmākabhakkho vā homi, nīvārabhakkho vā homi, daddulabhakkho vā homi, haṭabhakkho vā homi, kaṇabhakkho vā homi, ācāmabhakkho vā homi, piññākabhakkho vā homi, tiṇabhakkho vā homi, gomayabhakkho vā homi, vanamūlaphalāhāro yāpemi pavattaphalabhojī.
mn12:45.6.eng: I ate herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. I survived on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
mn12:45.6.comm: It is not easy to meaningfully distinguish the various kinds of grain.

mn12:45.7.pli: So sāṇānipi dhāremi, masāṇānipi dhāremi, chavadussānipi dhāremi, paṃsukūlānipi dhāremi, tirīṭānipi dhāremi, ajinampi dhāremi, ajinakkhipampi dhāremi, kusacīrampi dhāremi, vākacīrampi dhāremi, phalakacīrampi dhāremi, kesakambalampi dhāremi, vāḷakambalampi dhāremi, ulūkapakkhampi dhāremi;
mn12:45.7.eng: I wore robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
mn12:45.7.comm: All are extremely uncomfortable. Christian ascetics wore a “hair shirt” in order to “mortify the flesh” .

mn12:45.8.eng: I tore out hair and beard, committed to this practice.
mn12:45.8.comm: Jain ascetics tear out their hair at ordination, rather than shaving.

mn12:45.9.eng: I constantly stood, turning down seats.
mn12:45.9.comm: Remaining in one posture for months or years at a time is one of the most difficult practices.

mn12:45.10.eng: I squatted, committed to the endeavor of squatting.

mn12:45.11.eng: I lay on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns my bed.

mn12:45.12.eng: I was devoted to ritual bathing three times a day, including at dusk.
mn12:45.12.comm: The “three times” are daybreak, noon, and dusk, considered the three crucial “junctures” (sandhyā). This seems out of place here. It was a Brahmanical practice (SN 7.21), as the Jains refused to bathe at all, hence the “rough living” of the following section. Indeed, bathing three times a day in the Indian climate would, for most of the year, be quite pleasant. Sometimes, however, it was deliberately done in the cold (Ud 1.9:1.3).

mn12:45.13.pli: iti evarūpaṃ anekavihitaṃ kāyassa ātāpanaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto viharāmi.
mn12:45.13.eng: And so I lived committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body.

mn12:45.14.eng: Such was my practice of fervent mortification.

mn12:46.1.pli: Tatrāssu me idaṃ, sāriputta, lūkhasmiṃ hoti—
mn12:46.1.eng: And this is what my rough living was like.
mn12:46.1.comm: “Rough” (lūkha) is related to the Sanskrit rūkṣa, among the meanings of which is “soiled, smeared, dirtied”.

mn12:46.2.pli: nekavassagaṇikaṃ rajojallaṃ kāye sannicitaṃ hoti papaṭikajātaṃ.
mn12:46.2.eng: The dust and dirt built up on my body over many years until it started flaking off.

mn12:46.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, tindukakhāṇu nekavassagaṇiko sannicito hoti papaṭikajāto, evamevāssu me, sāriputta, nekavassagaṇikaṃ rajojallaṃ kāye sannicitaṃ hoti papaṭikajātaṃ.
mn12:46.3.eng: It’s like the trunk of a pale-moon ebony tree, which builds up bark over many years until it starts flaking off.

mn12:46.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, sāriputta, na evaṃ hoti:
mn12:46.4.eng: But it didn’t occur to me:

mn12:46.5.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ imaṃ rajojallaṃ pāṇinā parimajjeyyaṃ, aññe vā pana me imaṃ rajojallaṃ pāṇinā parimajjeyyun’ti.
mn12:46.5.eng: ‘Oh, this dust and dirt must be rubbed off by my hand or another’s.’

mn12:47.1.pli: Tatrāssu me idaṃ, sāriputta, jegucchismiṃ hoti—
mn12:47.1.eng: And this is what my living in disgust of sin was like.

mn12:47.2.pli: so kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, satova abhikkamāmi, satova paṭikkamāmi, yāva udakabindumhipi me dayā paccupaṭṭhitā hoti:
mn12:47.2.eng: I’d step forward or back ever so mindfully, so I was full of pity regarding even a drop of water, thinking:
mn12:47.2.comm: The Bodhisatta learned mindfulness while doing Jain-like practices and later incorporated it into the eightfold path (see also MN 36:20.7). He also learned mindfulness under Brahmanical teachers (MN 26:15.17). | “Pity” is dayā, which is similar to the more commonly found terms karuṇā or anukampa.

mn12:47.3.eng: ‘May I not injure any little creatures on unclear ground.’
mn12:47.3.comm: To this day, Jain ascetics carry a soft broom to gently sweep away any insects in their path. | “Unclear ground” (visamagata) is explained by the commentary as ground that is uneven or covered in grass, branches, etc. A lion is said to reflect in the same way when setting out on a hunt (AN 10.21:1.7). | Compare Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.10.2, where a man carrying a palanquin is so scrupulous about avoiding treading on ants that he stops and starts, making the progress of the palanquin unsteady (viṣama-gatāṁ).

mn12:47.4.eng: Such was my living in disgust of sin.

mn12:48.1.pli: Tatrāssu me idaṃ, sāriputta, pavivittasmiṃ hoti—
mn12:48.1.eng: And this is what my seclusion was like.
mn12:48.1.comm: “Seclusion” (viviktaśayyāsana) is classified by the Jains as an “external austerity” (bāhyatapas) at Tattvārthasūtra 9.19.

mn12:48.2.pli: so kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, aññataraṃ araññāyatanaṃ ajjhogāhetvā viharāmi.
mn12:48.2.eng: I would plunge deep into a wilderness region and stay there.

mn12:48.3.pli: Yadā passāmi gopālakaṃ vā pasupālakaṃ vā tiṇahārakaṃ vā kaṭṭhahārakaṃ vā vanakammikaṃ vā, vanena vanaṃ gahanena gahanaṃ ninnena ninnaṃ thalena thalaṃ sampatāmi.
mn12:48.3.eng: When I saw a cowherd or a shepherd, or someone gathering grass or sticks, or a lumberjack, I’d flee from forest to forest, from thicket to thicket, from valley to valley, from uplands to uplands.

mn12:48.5.pli: Mā maṃ te addasaṃsu ahañca mā te addasanti.
mn12:48.5.eng: So that I wouldn’t see them, nor they me.

mn12:48.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, āraññako mago manusse disvā vanena vanaṃ gahanena gahanaṃ ninnena ninnaṃ thalena thalaṃ sampatati;
mn12:48.6.eng: I fled like a wild deer seeing a human being.

mn12:48.7.pli: evameva kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, yadā passāmi gopālakaṃ vā pasupālakaṃ vā tiṇahārakaṃ vā kaṭṭhahārakaṃ vā vanakammikaṃ vā vanena vanaṃ gahanena gahanaṃ ninnena ninnaṃ thalena thalaṃ sampatāmi.

mn12:48.9.pli: Mā maṃ te addasaṃsu ahañca mā te addasanti.

mn12:48.10.eng: Such was my practice of seclusion.
mn12:48.10.comm: This concludes the “spiritual path consisting of four factors” of MN 12:44.1.

mn12:49.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, ye te goṭṭhā paṭṭhitagāvo apagatagopālakā, tattha catukkuṇḍiko upasaṅkamitvā yāni tāni vacchakānaṃ taruṇakānaṃ dhenupakānaṃ gomayāni tāni sudaṃ āhāremi.
mn12:49.1.eng: I would go on all fours into the cow-pens after the cattle had left and eat the dung of the young suckling calves.

mn12:49.2.pli: Yāvakīvañca me, sāriputta, sakaṃ muttakarīsaṃ apariyādinnaṃ hoti, sakaṃyeva sudaṃ muttakarīsaṃ āhāremi.
mn12:49.2.eng: As long as my own urine and excrement lasted, I would even eat that.

mn12:49.3.eng: Such was my eating of most unnatural things.
mn12:49.3.comm: At Kd 6:14.6.3 the four “great unnaturals” (or “filthy edibles”, mahāvikaṭa) are said to be feces, urine, ash, and clay.

mn12:50.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, aññataraṃ bhiṃsanakaṃ vanasaṇḍaṃ ajjhogāhetvā viharāmi.
mn12:50.1.eng: I would plunge deep into an awe-inspiring forest grove and stay there.

mn12:50.2.pli: Tatrāssudaṃ, sāriputta, bhiṃsanakassa vanasaṇḍassa bhiṃsanakatasmiṃ hoti—

mn12:50.3.pli: yo koci avītarāgo taṃ vanasaṇḍaṃ pavisati, yebhuyyena lomāni haṃsanti.
mn12:50.3.eng: normally it would make your hair stand on end if you weren’t free of greed.

mn12:50.4.pli: So kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, yā tā rattiyo sītā hemantikā antaraṭṭhakā himapātasamayā tathārūpāsu rattīsu rattiṃ abbhokāse viharāmi, divā vanasaṇḍe;
mn12:50.4.eng: And on days such as the cold spell when the snow falls in the January winter, I stayed in the open by night and in the forest by day.
mn12:50.4.comm: Antaraṭṭhakā (Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit aṣṭaka-rātri) is the coldest part of Indian winter between the festival days that fall on the eighth day after the fullmoon in the two winter months of Māgha and Phagguna. This roughly corresponds with January, the coldest month in northern India.

mn12:50.5.pli: gimhānaṃ pacchime māse divā abbhokāse viharāmi, rattiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
mn12:50.5.eng: But in the last month of summer I’d stay in the open by day and in the forest by night.

mn12:50.6.pli: Apissu maṃ, sāriputta, ayaṃ anacchariyagāthā paṭibhāsi pubbe assutapubbā:
mn12:50.6.eng: And then these verses, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, occurred to me:
mn12:50.6.comm: “Not supernaturally inspired” (anacchariyā) rejects the Vedic “channeling” of scripture from the Divinity, while “not learned before in the past” (pubbe assutapubbā), echoing the Dhammacakkappavattanasutta (SN 56.11:5.1), rejects the oral tradition.

mn12:50.9.eng: nude, no fire to sit beside,

mn12:50.10.eng: the sage still pursues his quest.’

mn12:51.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, susāne seyyaṃ kappemi chavaṭṭhikāni upadhāya.
mn12:51.1.eng: I would make my bed in a charnel ground, with the bones of the dead for a pillow.

mn12:51.2.pli: Apissu maṃ, sāriputta, gāmaṇḍalā upasaṅkamitvā oṭṭhubhantipi, omuttentipi, paṃsukenapi okiranti, kaṇṇasotesupi salākaṃ pavesenti.
mn12:51.2.eng: Then village louts would come up to me. They’d spit and piss on me, throw mud on me, even poke sticks in my ears.
mn12:51.2.comm: For “village louts” (gāmaṇḍalā), compare aṇḍaka in the sense “nasty, cruel” at MN 41:9.4.

mn12:51.3.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ, sāriputta, abhijānāmi tesu pāpakaṃ cittaṃ uppādetā.
mn12:51.3.eng: But I don’t recall ever having a bad thought about them.

mn12:51.4.eng: Such was my abiding in equanimity.

mn12:52.1.pli: Santi kho pana, sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn12:52.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

mn12:52.2.comm: Compare Chāndogya Upaniṣad 7.26.2: “from purity of food there is purity of being; from purity of being there is stable memory (mindfulness); relying on memory there is release from all ties” (āhāraśuddhau sattvaśuddhiḥ; sattvaśuddhau dhruvā smṛtiḥ; smṛtilambhe sarvagranthīnāṁ vipramokṣaḥ).

mn12:52.5.pli: Te kolampi khādanti, kolacuṇṇampi khādanti, kolodakampi pivanti—
mn12:52.5.eng: So they eat jujubes and jujube powder, and drink jujube juice.

mn12:52.6.eng: And they enjoy many jujube concoctions.

mn12:52.7.pli: Abhijānāmi kho panāhaṃ, sāriputta, ekaṃyeva kolaṃ āhāraṃ āhāritā.
mn12:52.7.eng: I recall eating just a single jujube.

mn12:52.8.pli: Siyā kho pana te, sāriputta, evamassa:

mn12:52.9.eng: at that time the jujubes must have been very big.

mn12:52.10.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, sāriputta, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
mn12:52.10.eng: But you should not see it like this.

mn12:52.11.pli: Tadāpi etaparamoyeva kolo ahosi seyyathāpi etarahi.
mn12:52.11.eng: The jujubes then were at most the same size as today.

mn12:52.12.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, sāriputta, ekaṃyeva kolaṃ āhāraṃ āhārayato adhimattakasimānaṃ patto kāyo hoti.
mn12:52.12.eng: Eating so very little, my body became severely emaciated.

mn12:52.13.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma āsītikapabbāni vā kāḷapabbāni vā; evamevassu me aṅgapaccaṅgāni bhavanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn12:52.13.eng: Due to eating so little, my major and minor limbs became like the joints of an eighty-year-old or a dying man,
mn12:52.13.comm: Āsītika is “eighty-year-old”, kāḷa is “time (of death)” (read kāla), pabba is “joint”.

mn12:52.14.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma oṭṭhapadaṃ; evamevassu me ānisadaṃ hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn12:52.14.eng: my bottom became like a camel’s hoof,

mn12:52.15.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma vaṭṭanāvaḷī; evamevassu me piṭṭhikaṇṭako unnatāvanato hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn12:52.15.eng: my vertebrae stuck out like beads on a string,

mn12:52.16.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma jarasālāya gopānasiyo oluggaviluggā bhavanti; evamevassu me phāsuḷiyo oluggaviluggā bhavanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn12:52.16.eng: and my ribs were as gaunt as the broken-down rafters on an old barn.

mn12:52.17.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma gambhīre udapāne udakatārakā gambhīragatā okkhāyikā dissanti; evamevassu me akkhikūpesu akkhitārakā gambhīragatā okkhāyikā dissanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn12:52.17.eng: Due to eating so little, the gleam of my eyes sank deep in their sockets, like the gleam of water sunk deep down a well.

mn12:52.18.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma tittakālābu āmakacchinno vātātapena samphuṭito hoti sammilāto; evamevassu me sīsacchavi samphuṭitā hoti sammilātā tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn12:52.18.eng: Due to eating so little, my scalp shriveled and withered like a green bitter-gourd in the wind and sun.

mn12:52.19.pli: So kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, ‘udaracchaviṃ parimasissāmī’ti piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṃyeva pariggaṇhāmi, ‘piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṃ parimasissāmī’ti udaracchaviṃyeva pariggaṇhāmi, yāvassu me, sāriputta, udaracchavi piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṃ allīnā hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn12:52.19.eng: Due to eating so little, the skin of my belly stuck to my backbone, so that when I tried to rub the skin of my belly I grabbed my backbone, and when I tried to rub my backbone I rubbed the skin of my belly.

mn12:52.20.pli: So kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, ‘vaccaṃ vā muttaṃ vā karissāmī’ti tattheva avakujjo papatāmi tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn12:52.20.eng: Due to eating so little, when I tried to urinate or defecate I fell face down right there.

mn12:52.21.pli: So kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, tameva kāyaṃ assāsento pāṇinā gattāni anomajjāmi. Tassa mayhaṃ, sāriputta, pāṇinā gattāni anomajjato pūtimūlāni lomāni kāyasmā patanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn12:52.21.eng: Due to eating so little, when I tried to relieve my body by rubbing my limbs with my hands, the hair, rotted at its roots, fell out.

mn12:53-55.1.pli: Santi kho pana, sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn12:53-55.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

mn12:53-55.7.pli: Te taṇḍulampi khādanti, taṇḍulacuṇṇampi khādanti, taṇḍulodakampi pivanti—

mn12:53-55.9.pli: Abhijānāmi kho panāhaṃ, sāriputta, ekaṃyeva taṇḍulaṃ āhāraṃ āhāritā.

mn12:53-55.10.pli: Siyā kho pana te, sāriputta, evamassa:

mn12:53-55.12.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, sāriputta, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.

mn12:53-55.13.pli: Tadāpi etaparamoyeva taṇḍulo ahosi, seyyathāpi etarahi.

mn12:53-55.14.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, sāriputta, ekaṃyeva taṇḍulaṃ āhāraṃ āhārayato adhimattakasimānaṃ patto kāyo hoti.

mn12:53-55.15.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma āsītikapabbāni vā kāḷapabbāni vā; evamevassu me aṅgapaccaṅgāni bhavanti tāyevappāhāratāya.

mn12:53-55.16.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma oṭṭhapadaṃ; evamevassu me ānisadaṃ hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.

mn12:53-55.17.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma vaṭṭanāvaḷī; evamevassu me piṭṭhikaṇṭako unnatāvanato hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.

mn12:53-55.18.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma jarasālāya gopānasiyo oluggaviluggā bhavanti; evamevassu me phāsuḷiyo oluggaviluggā bhavanti tāyevappāhāratāya.

mn12:53-55.19.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma gambhīre udapāne udakatārakā gambhīragatā okkhāyikā dissanti; evamevassu me akkhikūpesu akkhitārakā gambhīragatā okkhāyikā dissanti tāyevappāhāratāya.

mn12:53-55.20.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma tittakālābu āmakacchinno vātātapena samphuṭito hoti sammilāto; evamevassu me sīsacchavi samphuṭitā hoti sammilātā tāyevappāhāratāya.

mn12:53-55.21.pli: So kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, ‘udaracchaviṃ parimasissāmī’ti piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṃyeva pariggaṇhāmi, ‘piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṃ parimasissāmī’ti udaracchaviṃyeva pariggaṇhāmi. Yāvassu me, sāriputta, udaracchavi piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṃ allīnā hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.

mn12:53-55.22.pli: So kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, ‘vaccaṃ vā muttaṃ vā karissāmī’ti tattheva avakujjo papatāmi tāyevappāhāratāya.

mn12:53-55.23.pli: So kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, tameva kāyaṃ assāsento pāṇinā gattāni anomajjāmi. Tassa mayhaṃ, sāriputta, pāṇinā gattāni anomajjato pūtimūlāni lomāni kāyasmā patanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn12:53-55.23.eng: Due to eating so little, when I tried to relieve my body by rubbing my limbs with my hands, the hair, rotted at its roots, fell out.

mn12:56.1.pli: Tāyapi kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, iriyāya tāya paṭipadāya tāya dukkarakārikāya nājjhagamaṃ uttariṃ manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṃ.
mn12:56.1.eng: But Sāriputta, I did not achieve any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones by that conduct, that practice, that grueling work.

mn12:56.3.pli: Imissāyeva ariyāya paññāya anadhigamā, yāyaṃ ariyā paññā adhigatā ariyā niyyānikā, niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
mn12:56.3.eng: Because I didn’t achieve that noble wisdom that’s noble and emancipating, and which delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.

mn12:57.1.pli: Santi kho pana, sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn12:57.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

mn12:57.2.comm: A view attributed to Makkhali Gosāla (DN 2:21.3). The idea is that transmigration is limited, so one will automatically be released after a certain number of lives.

mn12:57.3.pli: Na kho pana so, sāriputta, saṃsāro sulabharūpo yo mayā asaṃsaritapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā, aññatra suddhāvāsehi devehi.
mn12:57.3.eng: But it’s not easy to find a realm that I haven’t previously transmigrated to in all this long time, except for the gods of the pure abodes.

mn12:57.4.pli: Suddhāvāse cāhaṃ, sāriputta, deve saṃsareyyaṃ, nayimaṃ lokaṃ punarāgaccheyyaṃ.
mn12:57.4.eng: For if I had transmigrated to the gods of the pure abodes I would not have returned to this realm again.
mn12:57.4.comm: The gods there are all “non-returners” and will attain arahantship in that realm.

mn12:58.1.pli: Santi kho pana, sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn12:58.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

mn12:58.2.comm: This view and the next appear to be different ways of repeating the same view as before. Perhaps there is a subtle difference between them.

mn12:58.3.pli: Na kho pana sā, sāriputta, upapatti sulabharūpā yā mayā anupapannapubbā iminā dīghena addhunā, aññatra suddhāvāsehi devehi.
mn12:58.3.eng: But it’s not easy to find any rebirth that I haven’t previously been reborn in …

mn12:58.4.pli: Suddhāvāse cāhaṃ, sāriputta, deve upapajjeyyaṃ, nayimaṃ lokaṃ punarāgaccheyyaṃ.

mn12:59.1.pli: Santi kho pana, sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn12:59.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

mn12:59.3.pli: Na kho pana so, sāriputta, āvāso sulabharūpo yo mayā anāvuṭṭhapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā, aññatra suddhāvāsehi devehi.
mn12:59.3.eng: But it’s not easy to find an abode where I haven’t previously abided …

mn12:59.4.pli: Suddhāvāse cāhaṃ, sāriputta, deve āvaseyyaṃ, nayimaṃ lokaṃ punarāgaccheyyaṃ.

mn12:60.1.pli: Santi kho pana, sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn12:60.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

mn12:60.2.comm: This is, of course, the brahmins.

mn12:60.3.pli: Na kho pana so, sāriputta, yañño sulabharūpo yo mayā ayiṭṭhapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā, tañca kho raññā vā satā khattiyena muddhāvasittena brāhmaṇena vā mahāsālena.
mn12:60.3.eng: But it’s not easy to find a sacrifice that I haven’t previously offered in all this long time, when I was an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin.

mn12:61.1.pli: Santi kho pana, sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn12:61.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

mn12:61.2.eng: ‘Purity comes from serving the sacred flame.’
mn12:61.2.comm: Again, serving the sacred flame is a fundamental, perhaps the fundamental, rite of the brahmins.

mn12:61.3.pli: Na kho pana so, sāriputta, aggi sulabharūpo yo mayā apariciṇṇapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā, tañca kho raññā vā satā khattiyena muddhāvasittena brāhmaṇena vā mahāsālena.
mn12:61.3.eng: But it’s not easy to find a fire that I haven’t previously served in all this long time, when I was an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin.

mn12:62.1.pli: Santi kho pana, sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn12:62.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

mn12:62.2.pli: ‘yāvadevāyaṃ bhavaṃ puriso daharo hoti yuvā susukāḷakeso bhadrena yobbanena samannāgato paṭhamena vayasā tāvadeva paramena paññāveyyattiyena samannāgato hoti.
mn12:62.2.eng: ‘So long as this gentleman is youthful, young, with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life he will be endowed with perfect lucidity of wisdom.

mn12:62.3.pli: Yato ca kho ayaṃ bhavaṃ puriso jiṇṇo hoti vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto, āsītiko vā nāvutiko vā vassasatiko vā jātiyā, atha tamhā paññāveyyattiyā, parihāyatī’ti.
mn12:62.3.eng: But when he’s old, elderly, and senior, advanced in years, and has reached the final stage of life—eighty, ninety, or a hundred years old—he will lose his lucidity of wisdom.’

mn12:62.4.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, sāriputta, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
mn12:62.4.eng: But you should not see it like this.

mn12:62.5.pli: Ahaṃ kho pana, sāriputta, etarahi jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto, āsītiko me vayo vattati.
mn12:62.5.eng: For now I am old, elderly, and senior, I’m advanced in years, and have reached the final stage of life. I am eighty years old.
mn12:62.5.comm: This situates this discourse, and hence the Sunakkhatta cycle as a whole, near the end of the Buddha’s life.

mn12:62.6.pli: Idha me assu, sāriputta, cattāro sāvakā vassasatāyukā vassasatajīvino, paramāya satiyā ca gatiyā ca dhitiyā ca samannāgatā paramena ca paññāveyyattiyena.
mn12:62.6.eng: Suppose I had four disciples with a lifespan of a hundred years. And they each were perfect in memory, range, retention, and perfect lucidity of wisdom.
mn12:62.6.comm: Memory (sati), range (gati), retention (dhiti), and perfect lucidity of wisdom (paññāveyyattiya).

mn12:62.7.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, daḷhadhammā dhanuggaho sikkhito katahattho katūpāsano lahukena asanena appakasireneva tiriyaṃ tālacchāyaṃ atipāteyya,
mn12:62.7.eng: Imagine how easily a well-trained expert archer with a strong bow would shoot a light arrow across the shadow of a palm tree.

mn12:62.8.pli: evaṃ adhimattasatimanto evaṃ adhimattagatimanto evaṃ adhimattadhitimanto evaṃ paramena paññāveyyattiyena samannāgatā.
mn12:62.8.eng: That’s how extraordinary they were in memory, range, retention, and perfect lucidity of wisdom.

mn12:62.9.pli: Te maṃ catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ upādāyupādāya pañhaṃ puccheyyuṃ, puṭṭho puṭṭho cāhaṃ tesaṃ byākareyyaṃ, byākatañca me byākatato dhāreyyuṃ, na ca maṃ dutiyakaṃ uttari paṭipuccheyyuṃ.
mn12:62.9.eng: They’d bring up questions about the four kinds of mindfulness meditation again and again, and I would answer each question. They’d remember the answers and not ask the same question twice.

mn12:62.10.pli: Aññatra asitapītakhāyitasāyitā aññatra uccārapassāvakammā, aññatra niddākilamathapaṭivinodanā apariyādinnāyevassa, sāriputta, tathāgatassa dhammadesanā, apariyādinnaṃyevassa tathāgatassa dhammapadabyañjanaṃ, apariyādinnaṃyevassa tathāgatassa pañhapaṭibhānaṃ.
mn12:62.10.eng: And they’d pause only to eat and drink, go to the toilet, and sleep to dispel weariness. But the Realized One would not run out of Dhamma teachings, words and phrases of the teachings, or spontaneous answers.

mn12:62.11.pli: Atha me te cattāro sāvakā vassasatāyukā vassasatajīvino vassasatassa accayena kālaṃ kareyyuṃ.
mn12:62.11.eng: And at the end of a hundred years my four disciples would pass away.

mn12:62.12.pli: Mañcakena cepi maṃ, sāriputta, pariharissatha, nevatthi tathāgatassa paññāveyyattiyassa aññathattaṃ.
mn12:62.12.eng: Even if you have to carry me around on a stretcher, there will never be any deterioration in the Realized One’s lucidity of wisdom.

mn12:63.1.pli: Yaṃ kho taṃ, sāriputta, sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
mn12:63.1.eng: And if there’s anyone of whom it may be rightly said that

mn12:63.2.pli: ‘asammohadhammo satto loke uppanno bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan’ti, mameva taṃ sammā vadamāno vadeyya
mn12:63.2.eng: a being not liable to delusion has arisen in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans, it’s of me that this should be said.”

mn12:63.3.pli: ‘asammohadhammo satto loke uppanno bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan’”ti.

mn12:64.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā nāgasamālo bhagavato piṭṭhito ṭhito hoti bhagavantaṃ bījayamāno.
mn12:64.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Nāgasamāla was standing behind the Buddha fanning him.
mn12:64.1.comm: We meet Nāgasamāla in less auspicious circumstances at Ud 8.7, where he stubbornly disagrees with the Buddha on which path to take.

mn12:64.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā nāgasamālo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn12:64.2.eng: Then he said to the Buddha:

mn12:64.4.pli: Api hi me, bhante, imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ sutvā lomāni haṭṭhāni.
mn12:64.4.eng: While I was listening to this exposition of the teaching my hair stood up!

mn12:64.5.eng: What is the name of this exposition of the teaching?”

mn12:64.6.pli: “Tasmātiha tvaṃ, nāgasamāla, imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ lomahaṃsanapariyāyotveva naṃ dhārehī”ti.
mn12:64.6.eng: “Well then, Nāgasamāla, you may remember this exposition of the teaching as ‘The Hair-raising Discourse’.”
mn12:64.6.comm: This original title is widely attested in the tradition, being found in some uddāna summary verses in Burmese and Sinhalese manuscripts, Mil 7.5.7:2.1, a Jātaka of the same name (Ja 94), several commentaries, and the Sanskrit and Chinese parallels. The subcommentary says that the name Mahāsīhanāda was given by the redactors.

mn12:64.7.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn12:64.8.pli: Attamano āyasmā nāgasamālo bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn12:64.8.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Nāgasamāla approved what the Buddha said.
